When they boiled their fish (which was done the most of the time) on account of no bread, the broth was used in place of tea, and don't think we didn't like it. We enjoyed it. Now it's hard to think of having to eat a boiled fish, much less have to drink the broth instead of tea.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) _________

How far was this water from your home? _________

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) _________

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

These parts are not far advanced in water supply. Most of us have wells, but many have no pump. The old bucket is used and wound up with a rope. Still carry it in pails to the house.

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made our own.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Soap, detergent.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? This country was all but coal oil lamps, stoves, and wood.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Wood is still used in stores but gas lights are used quite extensively the last 10 years or so not much longer. Almost there are no electric lights in our district here, not even self-owned plants. But a few miles away some have their own little power units.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or back oven? (Give dates)

There was an outdoor bake oven in the district (later).

By whom was your first cook stove made? Don't know.

That year was it purchased? Bought it from the store.

Iron pots and tin pans.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? These things were

Aluminum? General all over before we saw any out here, but they gradually came into the stores, better enamel ware than what we buy now it seems, or maybe we got so far, we took better care of them, we had to make them last longer.

16. **SHAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS**

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

To keep dry for hours even since we came here Canada we used to bury it just behind us the store before this. Bulk was the general way of buying we never got anything all fancy packed like now. Some of us bought meat etc came in wooden boxes.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast and supper were the same every day. We had meat, fish or go without. We used what we had. Sometimes we missed our tea. The most we ever had was tea. We had to get along on what tea was to get up on.

We were mother, (dad died in the flu) 3 boys and two girls. We boys averaged from 28 to 19 — the girls were younger.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Our times dinners were just another ordinary meal, with whatever extra mother would try to make out of nothing. No one came in so there were no fun and far between.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We never thought of it as starvation, but seem to me we would even call it that today as we got used to it and we were not hard to please as folks now days. (Always wanting a change.) We could eat fish week in and week out, we still love fish. We were different then all God must have made us that way as I don't think the younger generation could come down to live as we did and get along, they would sure think they were being abused, although they are some folks living that away today, and no need for it, their children are half good natured all the time.
15. Give a typical family scene (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. Tell the grandparents, mother, etc., enter-

Breakfast would be breakfast, dinner and supper would be dinner.

16. What did you serve for your first Christmas dinner in your home? (Give details.)

Christmas dinner was just another ordinary meal, with whatever extras mother could try to make out of nothing. No one ate in as they were no fun and no dinner.

19. Have you ever refused to almost starvation? Give details.

We never thought we'd starve to death today as we got well. But and we were not hard to please so if it had always been a change we would have made sure that way as I don't think the younger generation would come down to this as we did and get along, they would sure think they were having a hard time, although they are now quite well off.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

As soon as we could afford it, and had a means of getting it in line. We then bought as long as our money lasted. Same as folks do today.
